awd_titl_txt: Dimensions: Diversification of sensory systems in novel habitat: enhanced vision or compensation in other modalities?
awd_abstract_narration:
Understanding what helps and hinders rapid adaptation is crucial to predict organism responses to changing environments. Iceland's dynamic landscape provides a natural laboratory of fast-paced changes shaped by glaciers, volcanoes, and severe oceanic storms. The focus of this project is marine stickleback fish that have colonized multiple freshwater lakes, and thus have evolved in waters differing dramatically in clarity. The research examines sensory system evolution to ask if eyes get better at seeing in murky water, or if fish instead evolve better senses of smell and touch. The project identifies how genes and environment contribute to sensory system adaptation in different environments. The project gives young scientists cutting-edge training in multiple disciplines, generating a scientific workforce to help deal with large-scale environmental issues our society faces. Outreach efforts in museums and schools educate young and old alike on evolutionary changes driven by environmental change.

This research studies adaptation of sight, smell, and touch in extreme sensory environments. It assesses how differences in sensory systems affect survival from predators in murky glacial and clear lakes. The research reveals how genetic variation and gene expression differ, and reconstructs the history of colonization and the extent of parallel evolution of these traits in multiple lakes. It also uses transplant experiments to evaluate the extent of plasticity in sensory systems. This research combines the phenotypic and functional with the genetic dimensions of biodiversity, all within a historical context. Each dimension informs the other to help understand sensory adaptation.

por.por_cntn:
Scientific advances: What did we learn and why does it matter? 

We face severe world-wide effects from human-induced disturbance and are losing biodiversity at an alarming rate. Human-induced change far outpaces both the evolutionary responses of species and our ability to understand and manage such change. Our research asked if evolution is fast enough to keep up with changing environments, and is it predictable – does it occur in the same way repeatedly?

Sensory systems are critical for animals to persist in novel environments. Senses are essential, because animals gather information on their environment using sight, smell, taste, hearing, and touch to find food and avoid predators, and to communicate with social partners. 

We studied sensory adaptation of stickleback fish. Stickleback fish colonize diverse freshwater environments and can evolve very fast, making them ideal for understanding whether or not animals can adapt rapidly to extreme environments. We focused on adaptation in lakes created by glacial melting due to climate warming, working in Iceland which has hundreds of lakes with different ecology. Some lakes are glacially fed and cloudy, whereas others are spring fed and clear. Vision in cloudy glacial lakes is like looking through dense fog, with less than half the visibility of spring-fed lakes. Therefore, fish cannot easily see to navigate or to find food or social partners; nor see objects approaching and avoid predators. How do fish adapt when they cannot see well? Do they evolve to see better in glacial lakes, or instead switch to using their sense of smell or touch (detected through their lateral line)?

We gathered data on water visibility, described differences in senses, studied behavior in response to predators, studied how fish brains respond and evolve, and how fish microbiomes may influence their behavior.

We discovered that 1) sensory systems adapt to changing conditions, helping them to avoid predators. Fish from glacial lakes responded better to predator odor, and altered their escape behavior when they were in cloudy versus clear water, suggesting that smell has taken over for sight. Fish from clear lakes responded quickly to seeing a predator and used more evasive escape behavior, confirming they use vision effectively. 2) The lateral line (sense of touch) has also evolved. Fish from older glacial lakes show the biggest differences in this sense, suggesting that it evolves slowly. We also found that sensory evolution is partly predictable, because glacial populations evolved mostly in the same way, and spring-fed populations evolved to a similar value. 3) We discovered differences in brain structure, with glacial fish having larger brains overall, with larger brain regions for vision and lateral line, and smaller brain regions for smell. 4) We are still analyzing data on brain responses through expressing different sets of genes, but already know that the brain regions that process vision, smell, and lateral line information show differences for fish from glacial and spring-fed lakes, with the biggest differences in the brain area for the lateral line. 5) And lastly we found that the microbiome of fish from glacial and spring-fed lakes differs and is related to their behavioral response to predators.

Overall, we found substantial evolution in senses, but that this occurs over thousands instead of hundreds of years, and is partly but not fully predictable. Thus, policies humans develop to restore environments and protect species may be only partly successful. Our work studying stickleback illuminates a broad array of widespread evolutionary processes

Broader impacts:  

Our research addressed the effects of global climate change on evolutionary adaptation; a scientific and societal issue of great importance in our changing world. Understanding whether or not animals can adapt rapidly to novel environments, and whether this is predictable is essential for us to predict the response of organisms to global human-induced change, and hopefully can facilitate development of policies that conserve biodiversity.

Conserving biodiversity on earth helps our economy, gives us ecosystem services like clean water and air and places to live, and for ethical reasons. And also, it is healthy for our bodies, our minds, and our communities to have a healthy natural environment surrounding us. Many studies show that spending time in nature's diversity helps our mental and physical wellbeing and that healthy people make well-functioning communities. So, protecting our environment is valuable to us as individuals as well as to our communities and society at large. Our research furthered efforts to conserve the species that share our planet.

The project was highly multidisciplinary, and helped 18 scientists-in-training advance their knowledge and skills in biology, computing, and teaching to achieve their career goals, including high school and graduate students, postdoctoral scholars, and new assistant professors, helping to create a strong scientific workforce. It also advanced diversity in the sciences with respect to gender, race, disability, and LGBTQIA, and promoted international collaboration with Iceland, Sweden, Colombia and France.
